statements.name: PROC UCM
statements.description: The UCM procedure analyzes and forecasts equally spaced univariate time series data by using an unobserved components model (UCM). The UCMs are also called structural models in the time series literature. A UCM decomposes the response series into components such as trend, seasonals, cycles, and the regression effects due to predictor series. The components in the model are supposed to capture the salient features of the series that are useful in explaining and predicting its behavior. Harvey (1989) is a good reference for time series modeling that uses the UCMs. Harvey calls the components in a UCM the "stylized facts" about the series under consideration. Traditionally, the ARIMA models and, to some limited extent, the exponential smoothing models have been the main tools in the analysis of this type of time series data. It is fair to say that the UCMs capture the versatility of the ARIMA models while possessing the interpretability of the smoothing models. A thorough discussion of the correspondence between the ARIMA models and the UCMs, and the relative merits of UCM and ARIMA modeling, is given in Harvey (1989). The UCMs are also very similar to another set of models, called the dynamic models, that are popular in the Bayesian time series literature (West and Harrison 1999). In SAS/ETS you can use PROC ARIMA for ARIMA modeling, PROC ESM for exponential smoothing modeling , and use the Time Series Forecasting System for a point-and-click interface to ARIMA and exponential smoothing modeling.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the SAS data set containing the time series. If the DATA= option is not specified in the PROC UCM statement, the most recently created SAS data set is used.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Turns off all the printing for the procedure. The subsequent print options in the procedure are ignored.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Controls the plots produced with ODS Graphics. When you specify only one plot request, you can omit the parentheses around the plot request. Syntax: PLOTS<(global-plot-options)> <= plot-request <(options)>> PLOTS<(global-plot-options)> <= (plot-request <(options)> <... plot-request <(options)>>)> The following global-plot-option is supported:

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Produces all plots appropriate for the particular analysis.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all plots.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Syntax: FILTER(<filter-plot-options>) Produces time series plots of the filtered component estimates. The following filter-plot-options are available: ALL produces all the filtered component estimate plots appropriate for the particular analysis. LEVEL produces a time series plot of the filtered level component estimate, provided the model contains the level component. SLOPE produces a time series plot of the filtered slope component estimate, provided the model contains the slope component. CYCLE produces time series plots of the filtered cycle component estimates for all cycle components in the model, if there are any. SEASON produces time series plots of the filtered season component estimates for all seasonal components in the model, if there are any. DECOMP produces time series plots of the filtered estimates of the series decomposition.

arguments.name: RESIDUAL
arguments.description: Syntax: RESIDUAL(<residual-plot-options>) Produces the residuals plots. The following residual-plot-options are available: ALL produces all the residual diagnostics plots appropriate for the particular analysis. ACF produces the autocorrelation plot of residuals. CUSUM produces the plot of cumulative residuals against time. CUSUMSQ produces the plot of cumulative squared residuals against time. HISTOGRAM produces the histogram of residuals. LOESS produces a scatter plot of residuals against time, which has an overlaid loess-fit. PACF produces the partial-autocorrelation plot of residuals. PANEL produces a summary panel of the residual diagnostics consisting of the following: o histogram of residuals o normal quantile plot of residuals o the residual-autocorrelation-plot o the residual-partial-autocorrelation-plot QQ produces a normal quantile plot of residuals. RESIDUAL produces a needle plot of residuals against time. WN produces the plot of Ljung-Box white-noise test p-values at different lags (in log scale).

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Syntax: SMOOTH(<smooth-plot-options>) Produces time series plots of the smoothed component estimates. The following smooth-plot-options are available: ALL produces all the smoothed component estimate plots appropriate for the particular analysis. LEVEL produces time series plot of the smoothed level component estimate, provided the model contains the level component. SLOPE produces time series plot of the smoothed slope component estimate, provided the model contains the slope component. CYCLE produces time series plots of the smoothed cycle component estimates for all cycle components in the model, if there are any. SEASON produces time series plots of the smoothed season component estimates for all season components in the model, if there are any. DECOMP produces time series plots of the smoothed estimates of the series decomposition.

arguments.name: PRINTALL
arguments.description: Turns on all the printing options for the procedure. The subsequent NOPRINT options in the procedure are ignored.

statements.name: AUTOREG
statements.description: The AUTOREG statement specifies an autoregressive component in the model. An autoregressive component is a special case of cycle that corresponds to the frequency of zero or π. It is modeled separately for easier interpretation.
statements.help: AUTOREG <NOEST=<RHO | VARIANCE | RHO VARIANCE)>> <PLOT=<FILTER | SMOOTH | (FILTER SMOOTH)>> <PRINT=<FILTER | SMOOTH | (FILTER SMOOTH)>> ...

arguments.name: NOEST=
arguments.description: Fixes the values of ρ and ρ²γ to those specified in the RHO= and VARIANCE= options.

arguments.name: RHO
arguments.description: Fixes the value of ρ to the one specified in the RHO= option.

arguments.name: VARIANCE
arguments.description: Fixes the value of ρ²γ to the one specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: RHO
arguments.description: Fixes the values of ρ and ρ²γ to those specified in the RHO= and VARIANCE= options.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the autoreg component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered estimate of the autoreg component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the smoothed estimate of the autoreg component.

arguments.name: (FILTER SMOOTH)
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the autoreg component.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the autoreg component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the autoreg component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the autoreg component.

arguments.name: (FILTER SMOOTH)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the autoreg component.

arguments.name: RHO=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the damping factor ρ during the parameter estimation process. The value of ρ must be in the interval (–1, 1), including –1 but excluding 1.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the disturbance variance, ρ²γ, during the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.

statements.name: BLOCKSEASON
statements.description: The BLOCKSEASON or BLOCKSEASONAL statement is used to specify a seasonal component γt that has a special block structure. The seasonal γt is called a block seasonal of block size m and number of blocks k if its season length, s, can be factored as s=m*k and its seasonal effects have a block form—that is, the first m seasonal effects are all equal to some number τ-1, the next m effects are all equal to some number τ-2, and so on.

arguments.name: BLOCKSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the block size, m. This is a required option in this statement. The block size can be any integer larger than or equal to two. Typical examples of block sizes are 24, corresponding to the hours of the day when a day is being used as a block in hourly data, or 60, corresponding to the minutes in an hour when an hour is being used as a block in data recorded by minutes, etc.

arguments.name: NBLOCKS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of blocks, k. This is a required option in this statement. The number of blocks can be any integer greater than or equal to two.

arguments.name: NOEST
arguments.description: Specifies the value of the disturbance variance parameter to the value specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the position of the first measurement within the block, if the first measurement is not at the start of a block. The OFFSET= value must be between one and the block size. The default value is one. The first measurement refers to the start of the estimation span and the forecast span. If these spans differ, their starting measurements must be separated by an integer multiple of the block size.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plots of the season component. When you specify only one plot request, you can omit the parentheses around the plot request.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plot of the filtered estimates of the season component, γt.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plot of the smoothed estimates of the season component, γt.

arguments.name: F_ANNUAL
arguments.description: Requests plot of the "annual" variation in the filtered estimates of the season component, γt.

arguments.name: S_ANNUAL
arguments.description: Requests plot of the "annual" variation in the smoothed estimates of the season component, γt.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH> <F_ANNUAL> <S_ANNUAL>)
arguments.description: Requests plots for a combination of FILTER, SMOOTH, F_ANNUAL, and S_ANNUAL plot-requests.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the block season component, γt.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the block season component, γt.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the block season component, γt.

arguments.name: (FILTER SMOOTH)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the block season component, γt.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of the block seasonal component. The default type is DUMMY.

arguments.name: DUMMY
arguments.description: DUMMY [No description available]

arguments.name: TRIG
arguments.description: TRIG [No description available]

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the disturbance variance, σ²ω, in the γt equation at the start of the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used in the UCM procedure to process a data set in groups of observations defined by the BY variables. The model specified using the MODEL and other component statements is applied to all the groups defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in order of the BY variables. The variables are one or more variables in the input data set.

statements.name: CYCLE
statements.description: The CYCLE statement is used to specify a cycle component, ψt, in the model. There can be multiple cycles in a model, each specified using a separate CYCLE statement.

arguments.name: NOEST=
arguments.description: Fixes the values of the component parameters to those specified in the RHO=, PERIOD=, and VARIANCE= options. This option enables you to fix any combination of parameter values.

arguments.name: PERIOD
arguments.description: Fixes the value of period to the one specified in the PERIOD= option.

arguments.name: RHO
arguments.description: Fixes the value of ρ to the one specified in the RHO= option.

arguments.name: VARIANCE
arguments.description: Fixes the value of γ to the one specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: <PERIODZ> <RHO> <VARIANCE>)
arguments.description: Fixes the values of period, ρ and/or variance to those specified in the RHO= and VARIANCE= options.

arguments.name: PERIOD=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the cycle period during the parameter estimation process. Period value must be strictly greater than 2.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the cycle component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered estimate of the cycle component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the smoothed estimate of the cycle component.

arguments.name: (FILTER SMOOTH)
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the cycle component.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the cycle component ψt.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the cycle component ψt.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the cycle component ψt.

arguments.name: (FILTER SMOOTH)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the cycle component ψt.

arguments.name: RHO=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the damping factor ρ during the parameter estimation process. Any value of ρ in the interval (0, 1), including 1 but excluding zero, is an acceptable initial value for the damping factor.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the disturbance variance, σ²v, to be used during the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.

statements.name: DEPLAG
statements.description: The DEPLAG statement is used to specify the lags of the dependent variable to be included as predictors in the model.

arguments.name: LAGS=
arguments.description: Is a required option in this statement. LAGS=(l1, l2,..., lk) defines a model with specified lags of the dependent variable included as predictors. LAGS=order is equivalent to LAGS=(1, 2, ..., order ).

arguments.name: NOEST
arguments.description: Fixes the values of the parameters to those specified in PHI= option.

arguments.name: PHI=
arguments.description: Lists starting values for the coefficients of the lagged dependent variable. The order of the values listed corresponds with the order of the lags specified in the LAGS= option.

statements.name: ESTIMATE
statements.description: The ESTIMATE statement is an optional statement used to control the overall model-fitting environment. Using this statement, you can control the span of observations used to fit the model by using the SKIPFIRST= and BACK= options. This can be useful in model diagnostics. You can request a variety of goodness-of-fit statistics and other model diagnostic information including different residual diagnostic plots. Note that the ESTIMATE statement is not used to control the nonlinear optimization process itself. That is done using the NLOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: BACK=
arguments.description: Indicates that some ending part of the data needs to be ignored during the parameter estimation. This can be useful when you want to study the forecasting performance of a model on the observed data. BACK=10 results in skipping the last 10 measurements of the response series during the parameter estimation. The default is BACK=0.

arguments.name: EXTRADIFFUSE=
arguments.description: Enables continuation of the diffuse filtering iterations for k additional iterations beyond the first instance where the initialization of the diffuse state would have otherwise taken place. If the specified k is larger than the sample size, the diffuse iterations continue until the end of the sample. Note that one-step-ahead residuals are produced only after the diffuse state is initialized. Delaying the initialization leads to a reduction in the number of one-step-ahead residuals available for computing the residual diagnostic measures. This option is useful when you want to ignore the first few one-step-ahead residuals that often have large variance.

arguments.name: NOPROFILE
arguments.description: Requests that the usual likelihood be optimized for parameter estimation.

arguments.name: OUTEST=
arguments.description: Specifies an output data set for the estimated parameters.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests different residual diagnostic plots.
arguments.help: PLOT=ACF | CUSUM | CUSUMSQ | MODEL | HISTOGRAM | LOESS | PACF | PANEL | QQ | RESIDUAL | WN

arguments.name: ACF
arguments.description: Produces the residual-autocorrelation plot.

arguments.name: CUSUM
arguments.description: Produces the plot of cumulative residuals against time.

arguments.name: CUSUMSQ
arguments.description: Produces the plot of cumulative squared residuals against time.

arguments.name: MODEL
arguments.description: Produces the plot of one-step-ahead forecasts in the estimation span.

arguments.name: HISTOGRAM
arguments.description: Produces the histogram of residuals.

arguments.name: LOESS
arguments.description: Produces a scatter plot of residuals against time, which has an overlaid loess-fit.

arguments.name: PACF
arguments.description: Produces the residual-partial-autocorrelation plot.

arguments.name: PANEL
arguments.description: Produces a summary panel of the residual diagnostics consisting of: o histogram of residuals o normal quantile plot of residuals o the residual-autocorrelation-plot o the residual-partial-autocorrelation-plot

arguments.name: QQ
arguments.description: Produces a normal quantile plot of residuals.

arguments.name: RESIDUAL
arguments.description: Produces a needle plot of residuals against time.

arguments.name: WN
arguments.description: Produces a plot of p-values, in log-scale, at different lags for the Ljung-Box portmanteau white noise test statistics.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Suppresses all the printed output related to the model fitting, such as the parameter estimates, the goodness-of-fit statistics, and so on.

arguments.name: PROFILE
arguments.description: Requests that the profile likelihood, obtained by concentrating out one of the disturbance variances from the likelihood, be optimized for parameter estimation. By default, the profile likelihood is not optimized if any of the disturbance variance parameters is held fixed to a nonzero value.

arguments.name: SKIPFIRST=
arguments.description: Indicates that some early part of the data needs to be ignored during the parameter estimation. This can be useful if there is a reason to believe that the model being estimated is not appropriate for this portion of the data. SKIPFIRST=10 results in skipping the first 10 measurements of the response series during the parameter estimation. The default is SKIPFIRST=0.

statements.name: FORECAST
statements.description: The FORECAST statement is an optional statement that is used to specify the overall forecasting environment for the specified model. It can be used to specify the span of observations, the historical period, to use to compute the forecasts of the future observations. This is done using the SKIPFIRST= and BACK= options. The number of periods to forecast beyond the historical period, and the significance level of the forecast confidence interval, is specified using the LEAD= and ALPHA= options. You can request one-step-ahead series and component forecasts by using the PRINT= option. You can save the series forecasts, and the model-based decomposition of the series, in a data set by using the OUTFOR= option.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level of the forecast confidence intervals; for example, ALPHA=0.05, which is the default, results in a 95% confidence interval.

arguments.name: BACK=
arguments.description: Specifies the holdout sample for the evaluation of the forecasting performance of the model. For example, BACK=10 results in treating the last 10 observed values of the response series as unobserved. A post-sample-prediction-analysis table is produced for comparing the predicted values with the actual values in the holdout period. The default is BACK=0.

arguments.name: EXTRADIFFUSE=
arguments.description: Enables continuation of the diffuse filtering iterations for k additional iterations beyond the first instance where the initialization of the diffuse state would have otherwise taken place. If the specified k is larger than the sample size, the diffuse iterations continue until the end of the sample.

arguments.name: LEAD=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of periods to forecast beyond the historical period defined by the SKIPFIRST= and BACK= options; for example, LEAD=10 results in the forecasting of 10 future values of the response series. The default is LEAD=12.

arguments.name: OUTFOR=
arguments.description: Specifies an output data set for the forecasts. The output data set contains the ID variable (if specified), the response and predictor series, the one-step-ahead and out-of-sample response series forecasts, the forecast confidence intervals, the smoothed values of the response series, and the smoothed forecasts produced as a result of the model-based decomposition of the series.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests forecast and model decomposition plots.
arguments.help: PLOT=DECOMP | DECOMPVAR | FDECOMP | FDECOMPVAR | FORECASTS | TREND | (<DECOMP> <DECOMPVAR> <FDECOMP> <FDECOMPVAR> <FORECASTS> <TREND>)

arguments.name: DECOMP
arguments.description: Provides plot of the decomposition estimates.

arguments.name: DECOMPVAR
arguments.description: Provides plot of the variance of model decomposition estimates.

arguments.name: FDECOMP
arguments.description: Provides plot for the filtered decomposition estimates.

arguments.name: FDECOMPVAR
arguments.description: Provides plot for the filtered decomposition estimates and their variances.

arguments.name: FORECASTS
arguments.description: Provides plot of the series forecasts.

arguments.name: TREND
arguments.description: Provides plot of the smoothed trend.

arguments.name: (<DECOMP> <DECOMPVAR> <FDECOMP> <FDECOMPVAR> <FORECASTS> <TREND>)
arguments.description: Requests a combination of forecast and model decomposition plots.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Controls the printing of the series forecasts and the printing of smoothed model decomposition estimates. By default, the series forecasts are printed only for the forecast horizon specified by the LEAD= option; that is, the one-step-ahead predicted values are not printed.

arguments.name: DECOMP
arguments.description: Prints smoothed estimates of the following effects: trend, trend plus regression, trend plus regression plus cycle, and sum of all components except the irregular.

arguments.name: FDECOMP
arguments.description: Prints filtered estimates of DECOMP effects.

arguments.name: FORECASTS
arguments.description: Requests printing of forecasts for the entire forecast span.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses the printing of all the forecast output.

arguments.name: (<DECOMP> <FDECOMP> <FORECASTS>)
arguments.description: Requests a combination of print options.

arguments.name: SKIPFIRST=
arguments.description: Indicates that some early part of the data needs to be ignored during the forecasting calculations. This can be useful if there is a reason to believe that the model being used for forecasting is not appropriate for this portion of the data. SKIPFIRST=10 results in skipping the first 10 measurements of the response series during the forecast calculations. The default is SKIPFIRST=0.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement names a numeric variable that identifies observations in the input and output data sets. The ID variable’s values are assumed to be SAS date, time, or datetime values. In addition, the ID statement specifies the frequency associated with the time series.

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: Controls the alignment of SAS dates used to identify output observations. The ALIGN= option is used to align the ID variable with the beginning, middle, or end of the time ID interval specified by the INTERVAL= option.

arguments.name: BEGINNING
arguments.description: Aligns the ID variable with the beginning of the time ID interval specified by the INTERVAL= option.

arguments.name: MIDDLE
arguments.description: Aligns the ID variable with the middle of the time ID interval specified by the INTERVAL= option.

arguments.name: ENDING
arguments.description: Aligns the ID variable with the end of the time ID interval specified by the INTERVAL= option.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the time interval between observations. This option is required in the ID statement.
arguments.help: INTERVAL=DAY | HOUR | MINUTE | SECOND | WEEK | MONTH | YEAR | QTR | TENDAY | SEMIMONTH | SEMIYEAR

arguments.name: DAY
arguments.description: DAY interval

arguments.name: HOUR
arguments.description: HOUR interval

arguments.name: MINUTE
arguments.description: MINUTE interval

arguments.name: SECOND
arguments.description: SECOND interval

arguments.name: WEEK
arguments.description: WEEK interval

arguments.name: MONTH
arguments.description: MONTH interval

arguments.name: YEAR
arguments.description: YEAR interval

arguments.name: QTR
arguments.description: QTR interval

arguments.name: TENDAY
arguments.description: TENDAY interval

arguments.name: SEMIMONTH
arguments.description: SEMIMONTH interval

arguments.name: SEMIYEAR
arguments.description: SEMIYEAR interval

statements.name: IRREGULAR
statements.description: The IRREGULAR statement includes an irregular component in the model. There can be at most one IRREGULAR statement in the model specification. The irregular component corresponds to the overall random error, εt, in the model. By default the irregular component is modeled as white noise—that is, as a sequence of independent, identically distributed, zero-mean, Gaussian random variables. However, you can also model it as an autoregressive moving-average (ARMA) process.

arguments.name: AR=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: MA=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: NOEST
arguments.description: Fixes the value of σ²ε to the value specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: NOEST=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: P=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the irregular component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered estimate of the irregular component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the smoothed estimate of the irregular component.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the irregular component.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the irregular component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the irregular component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the irregular component.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the irregular component.

arguments.name: Q=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: S=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: SAR=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: SMA=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: SP=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: SQ=
arguments.description: [ARMA Specification Option]

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for σ²є during the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.

statements.name: LEVEL
statements.description: The LEVEL statement is used to include a level component in the model. The level component, either by itself or together with a slope component (see the SLOPE statement), forms the trend component, µt, of the model.

arguments.name: CHECKBREAK
arguments.description: Turns on the checking of breaks in the level component.

arguments.name: NOEST
arguments.description: Fixes the value of σ²η to the value specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the level component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered estimate of the level component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the smoothed estimate of the level component.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the level component.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the irregular component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the level component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the level component.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the level component.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for σ²η, the disturbance variance in the µt equation at the start of the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement specifies the response variable and, optionally, the predictor or regressor variables for the UCM model. This is a required statement in the UCM procedure. The predictors specified in the MODEL statement are assumed to have a linear and time-invariant relationship with the response. The predictors that have time-varying regression coefficients are specified separately in the RANDOMREG statement. Similarly, the predictors that have a nonlinear effect on the response variable are specified separately in the SPLINEREG statement. Only one MODEL statement can be specified.

statements.name: NLOPTIONS
statements.description: PROC UCM uses the nonlinear optimization (NLO) subsystem to perform the nonlinear optimization of the likelihood function during the estimation of model parameters. You can use the NLOPTIONS statement to control different aspects of this optimization process. For most problems the default settings of the optimization process are adequate. However, in some cases it might be useful to change the optimization technique or to change the maximum number of iterations. This can be done by using the TECH= and MAXITER= options in the NLOPTIONS statement as follows: nloptions tech=dbldog maxiter=200;

arguments.name: ABSCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value of r is the negative square root of the largest double-precision value, which serves only as a protection against overflows.

arguments.name: ABSFCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion. The default value is r=0. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: ABSGCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute gradient convergence criterion. The default value is r=1E-5. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: ABSXCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute parameter convergence criterion. The default is r=1E-8 for the NMSIMP technique and r=0 otherwise. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can terminate.

arguments.name: DAMPSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies that the initial step length value a⁰ for each line search (used by the QUANEW, HYQUAN, CONGRA, or NEWRAP technique) cannot be larger than r times the step length value used in the former iteration. If the DAMPSTEP option is specified but r is not specified, the default is r=2. The DAMPSTEP=r option can prevent the line-search algorithm from repeatedly stepping into regions where some objective functions are difficult to compute or where they could lead to floating point overflows during the computation of objective functions and their derivatives. The DAMPSTEP=r option can save time-costly function calls during the line searches of objective functions that result in very small steps.

arguments.name: FCONV2=
arguments.description: Specifies another function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

arguments.name: GCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative gradient convergence criterion. The default value is r=1E-8. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can terminate.

arguments.name: HESCAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the scaling version of the Hessian matrix used in NRRIDG, TRUREG, NEWRAP, or DBLDOG optimization.
Specifies that no scaling is done.
Specifies the Moré (1978) scaling update
Specifies the Dennis, Gay, and Welsch (1981) scaling update
Specifies that di is reset in each iteration

arguments.name: INHESSIAN=
arguments.description: Specifies how the initial estimate of the approximate Hessian is defined for the quasi-Newton techniques QUANEW and DBLDOG.

arguments.name: INSTEP=
arguments.description: Reduces the length of the first trial step during the line search of the first iterations.

arguments.name: LINESEARCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the line-search method for the CONGRA, QUANEW, and NEWRAP optimization techniques.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is similar to one used by the Harwell subroutine library.

Specifies a line-search method that needs more function calls than gradient calls for quadratic and cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for stepwise extrapolation and cubic interpolation
Specifies a line-search method that is a modified version of LIS=4.
Specifies golden section line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies bisection line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies Armijo line-search technique (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.

arguments.name: LSPRECISION=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of accuracy that should be obtained by the line-search algorithms LIS=2 and LIS=3. The default LSPRECISION= values are:

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Requires the number of function calls to be no larger than i. The default values are:

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Requires the number of iterations to be no larger than i. The default values are: o For TECH= TRUREG, NRRIDG, NEWRAP: i=50 o For TECH= QUANEW, DBLDOG: i=200 o For TECH= CONGRA: i=400 o For TECH= NMSIMP: i=1000 These default values are also valid when i is specified as a missing value.

arguments.name: MAXSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper bound for the step length of the line-search algorithms during the first n iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Requires the CPU time to be no larger than r. The default value of the MAXTIME= option is the largest double floating-point number on your computer. Note that the time specified by the MAXTIME= option is checked only once at the end of each iteration. Therefore, the actual running time can be much longer than that specified by the MAXTIME= option. The actual running time includes the rest of the time needed to finish the iteration and the time needed to generate the output of the results.

arguments.name: MINITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0. If you request more iterations than are actually needed for convergence to a stationary point, the optimization algorithms can behave strangely. For example, the effect of rounding errors can prevent the algorithm from continuing for the required number of iterations.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the output.

arguments.name: PALL
arguments.description: [Displays all optional output for optimization.

arguments.name: PHISTORY
arguments.description: Displays the optimization history.

arguments.name: PHISTPARMS
arguments.description: Display parameter estimates in each iteration.

arguments.name: PINIT
arguments.description: Displays the initial values and derivatives (if available).

arguments.name: PSHORT
arguments.description: Restricts the amount of default output.

arguments.name: PSUMMARY
arguments.description: Restricts the amount of default displayed output to a short form of iteration history and notes, warnings, and errors.

arguments.name: RESTART=
arguments.description: Specifies that the QUANEW or CONGRA algorithm is restarted with a steepest descent/ascent search direction after, at most, i iterations, i > 0.

arguments.name: SOCKET=
arguments.description: Specifies the fileref that contains the information needed for remote monitoring.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique.
arguments.help: TECHNIQUE=CONGRA | DBLDOG | NMSIMP | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG | NONE

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different conjugate-gradient optimization algorithms, which can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization, which uses the gradient to update an approximation of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian.

arguments.name: NMSIMP
arguments.description: Performs a Nelder-Mead simplex optimization.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. The algorithm combines a line-search algorithm with ridging, and it can be modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. This algorithm does not perform a line search.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different quasi-Newton optimization algorithms that can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Performs a usually very stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming trust-region optimization technique. The algorithm is implemented similar to Gay (1983) and Moré and Sorensen (1983).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Does not perform any optimization. This option is similar to METHOD=NONE, but TECH=NONE also computes and displays residuals and goodness of fit statistics.

arguments.name: UPDATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the update method for the quasi-Newton, double-dogleg, or conjugate-gradient optimization technique.
arguments.help: UPDATE=BFGS | DBFGS | DDFP | DFP | PB | FR | PR | CD

arguments.name: BFGS
arguments.description: Performs the original Broyden, Fletcher, Goldfarb, and Shanno (BFGS) update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DBFGS
arguments.description: Performs the dual BFGS update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix. This is the default update method.

arguments.name: DDFP
arguments.description: Performs the dual Davidon, Fletcher, and Powell (DFP) update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DFP
arguments.description: Performs the original DFP update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: PB
arguments.description: Performs the automatic restart update method of Powell (1977) and Beale (1972).

arguments.name: FR
arguments.description: Performs the Fletcher-Reeves update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: PR
arguments.description: Performs the Polak-Ribiere update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: CD
arguments.description: Performs a conjugate-descent update of Fletcher (1987).

arguments.name: XCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. For all techniques except NMSIMP, termination requires a small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations. The default value is r=1E-8 for the NMSIMP technique and r=0 otherwise. The optional integer value n specifies the number of successive iterations for which the criterion must be satisfied before the process can be terminated.

arguments.name: XSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative parameter termination criterion. The default value is r=0.

statements.name: OUTLIER
statements.description: The OUTLIER statement enables you to control the reporting of the additive outliers (AO) and level shifts (LS) in the response series. The AOs are searched by default. You can turn on the search for LSs by using the CHECKBREAK option in the LEVEL statement.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level for reporting the outliers. The default is 0.05.

arguments.name: MAXNUM=
arguments.description: Limits the number of outliers to search. The default is MAXNUM=5.

arguments.name: MAXPCT=
arguments.description: Is similar to the MAXNUM= option. In the MAXPCT= option you can limit the number of outliers to search for according to a percentage of the series length. The default is MAXPCT=1. When both of these options are specified, the minimum of the two search numbers is used.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Enables you to control the printed output of the outlier search.

arguments.name: SHORT
arguments.description: Produces an outlier summary table containing the most significant outliers, either AO or LS, discovered in the outlier search.

arguments.name: DETAIL
arguments.description: Produces, in addition to the outlier summary table, separate tables containing the AO and LS structural break chi² statistics computed at each time point in the estimation span.

statements.name: RANDOMREG
statements.description: The RANDOMREG statement is used to specify regressors with time-varying regression coefficients. Each regression coefficient is assumed to evolve as a random walk.

arguments.name: NOEST
arguments.description: Fixes the value of σ² to the value specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the smoothed estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for σ² during the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.

statements.name: SEASON
statements.description: The SEASON or SEASONAL statement is used to specify a seasonal component, γt, in the model. A seasonal component can be one of the two types, DUMMY or TRIG.
statements.help: SEASON <DROPHARMONICS|DROPH=number-list | n TO m BY p> <KEEPHARMONICS|KEEPH=number-list | n TO m BY p> <LENGTH=integer> ...

arguments.name: DROPHARMONICS=
arguments.description: Enables you to drop some harmonics γ-j,t from the full set of harmonics used to obtain a trigonometric seasonal. The drop list can include any integer between 1 and [s/2], s being the season length.

arguments.name: KEEPHARMONICS=
arguments.description: Enables you to keep only the harmonics γ-j,t listed in the option to obtain a trigonometric seasonal. The keep list can include any integer between 1 and [s/2], s being the season length.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the season length, s. This is a required option in this statement. The season length can be any integer greater than or equal to 2. Typical examples of season lengths are 12, corresponding to the monthly seasonality, or 4, corresponding to the quarterly seasonality.

arguments.name: NOEST
arguments.description: Fixes the value of the disturbance variance parameter to the value specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plots of the season component. When you specify only one plot request, you can omit the parentheses around the plot request.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plot of the filtered estimates of the season component, γt.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plot of the smoothed estimates of the season component, γt.

arguments.name: F_ANNUAL
arguments.description: Requests plot of the "annual" variation in the filtered estimates of the season component, γt.

arguments.name: S_ANNUAL
arguments.description: Requests plot of the "annual" variation in the smoothed estimates of the season component, γt.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH> <F_ANNUAL> <S_ANNUAL>)
arguments.description: Requests plots for a combination of FILTER, SMOOTH, F_ANNUAL, and S_ANNUAL plot-requests.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the seasonal component, γt.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the seasonal component, γt.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the seasonal component, γt.

arguments.name: (<FILTER SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the seasonal component, γt.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the summary of harmonics present in the seasonal component. This option is valid only for the trigonometric seasonal component.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of the seasonal component. The default type is DUMMY.

arguments.name: DUMMY
arguments.description: DUMMY [No description available]

arguments.name: TRIG
arguments.description: TRIG [No description available]

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the disturbance variance, σ²ω, σ in the γt equation at the start of the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.

statements.name: SLOPE
statements.description: The SLOPE statement is used to include a slope component in the model. The slope component cannot be used without the level component (see the LEVEL statement). The level and slope specifications jointly define the trend component of the model. A SLOPE statement without the accompanying LEVEL statement is ignored.

arguments.name: NOEST
arguments.description: Fixes the value of the disturbance variance, σ²ξ, to the value specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the slope component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered estimate of the slope component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the smoothed estimate of the slope component.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the slope component.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the slope component, βt.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the slope component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the slope component.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the slope component.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the disturbance variance, σ²ξ, in the βt equation at the start of the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.

statements.name: SPLINEREG
statements.description: The SPLINEREG statement is used to specify a regressor that has a nonlinear relationship with the dependent series that can be approximated by a given β-spline. If the specified spline has degree d and is based on n internal knots, then it is known that it can be written as a linear combination of (n + d + 1) regressors that are derived from the original regressor. The span of these (n + d + 1) derived regressors includes constant; therefore, to avoid multicollinearity with the level component, one of these regressors is dropped. Specifying the SPLINEREG statement is equivalent to specifying a RANDOMREG statement with these derived regressors. There can be multiple SPLINEREG statements. You must specify at least one interior knot, either using the NKNOTS= option or the KNOTS= option.
statements.help: SPLINEREG <DEGREE=integer> <KNOTS=number-list | n TO m BY p> <NKNOTS=m> ...

arguments.name: DEGREE=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of the spline. It can be any integer larger than or equal to zero. The default value is 3. The polynomial degree should be a small integer, usually 0, 1, 2, or 3. Larger values are rarely useful. If you have any doubt as to what degree to specify, use the default.

arguments.name: KNOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the interior knots or break points. The values in the knot list must be nondecreasing and must lie between the minimum and the maximum of the spline regressor values in the input data set. The first time you specify a value in the knot list, it indicates a discontinuity in the th (from DEGREE=n) derivative of the transformation function at the value of the knot. The second mention of a value indicates a discontinuity in the th derivative of the transformation function at the value of the knot. Knots can be repeated any number of times for decreasing smoothness at the break points, but the values in the knot list can never decrease.

arguments.name: NKNOTS=
arguments.description: Creates m knots, the first at the 100/(m+1) percentile, the second at the 200/(m+1) percentile, and so on. Knots are always placed at data values; there is no interpolation. For example, if NKNOTS=3, knots are placed at the 25th percentile, the median, and the 75th percentile. The value specified for the NKNOTS= option must be ≥ 1. You cannot use the NKNOTS=option with the KNOTS= option.

arguments.name: NOEST
arguments.description: Fixes the value of the regression coefficient random walk disturbance variance to the value specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the smoothed estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: (FILTER SMOOTH)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the time-varying regression coefficient.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the regression coefficient random walk disturbance variance during the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.

statements.name: SPLINESEASON
statements.description: The SPLINESEASON statement is used to specify a seasonal pattern that is to be approximated by a given β-spline. If the specified spline has degree d and is based on n internal knots, then it can be written as a linear combination of (n + d) regressors that are derived from the seasonal dummy regressors. The SPLINESEASON specification is equivalent to specifying a RANDOMREG specification with these derived regressors. Such approximation is useful only if the season length is relatively large, at least larger than (n + d).

arguments.name: DEGREE=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of the spline. It can be any integer larger than or equal to zero. The default value is 3.

arguments.name: KNOTS=
arguments.description: Lists the internal knots. This list of values must be a nondecreasing sequence of integers within the range of 2 to (s - 1), where s is the season length specified in the LENGTH= option. This is a required option in this statement.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the season length, s. This is a required option in this statement. The length can be any integer greater than or equal to three.

arguments.name: NOEST
arguments.description: Fixes the value of the regression coefficient random walk disturbance variance to the value specified in the VARIANCE= option.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the position of the first measurement within the season, if the first measurement is not at the start of the season. The OFFSET= value must be between one and the season length. The default value is one. The first measurement refers to the start of the estimation span and the forecast span. If these spans differ, their starting measurements must be separated by an integer multiple of the season length.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the season component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered estimate of the season component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the smoothed estimate of the season component.

arguments.name: (<FILTER> <SMOOTH>)
arguments.description: Requests plotting of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the season component.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered or smoothed estimate of the spline season component.

arguments.name: FILTER
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered estimate of the spline season component.

arguments.name: SMOOTH
arguments.description: Requests printing of the smoothed estimate of the spline season component.

arguments.name: (FILTER SMOOTH)
arguments.description: Requests printing of the filtered and smoothed estimates of the spline season component.

arguments.name: RKNOTS=
arguments.description: Specifies a grouping of knots such that the knots within the same group have identical seasonal values. The knots specified in this option must already be present in the list specified by the KNOTS= option. The knot groups must be non-overlapping and without any repeated knots.

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Specifies an initial value for the regression coefficient random walk disturbance variance during the parameter estimation process. Any nonnegative value, including zero, is an acceptable starting value.
